author: BNO News
message: BREAKING: Reports of heavy explosions and low-flying aircraft over Caracas, Venezuela. Local residents reporting power outages and intense military activity near Fort Tiuna.

author: Caitlin Dickerson (The Atlantic)
message: Sources in Caracas describe a 'coordinated assault' on government buildings. The scale of the air activity suggests a major foreign intervention is underway.

author: RealDonaldTrump (Truth Social)
message: A GREAT DAY FOR FREEDOM! At my direction, U.S. forces have captured the outlaw dictator Nicolas Maduro and his wife in Caracas. They are currently in U.S. custody. More to follow!

author: AP Central Am
message: URGENT: President Trump announces the capture of Nicolas Maduro during a midnight raid in the Venezuelan capital. Operation codenamed 'Absolute Resolve.'

author: CNN Breaking News
message: U.S. Department of War confirms Maduro and Cilia Flores were extracted by Delta Force and CIA operatives. No U.S. casualties reported in the mission.

author: Marco Rubio (SecState)
message: The days of the Maduro crime family are over. Justice is coming for the people of Venezuela. The U.S. will assist in a peaceful transition to legitimate governance.

author: Reuters World
message: Venezuelan VP Delcy Rodriguez denounces Maduro's capture as an 'imperialist kidnapping' and calls for immediate international condemnation.

author: The New York Times
message: Pentagon officials say over 150 aircraft were involved in 'Operation Absolute Resolve' to provide cover for the ground extraction of the Venezuelan leader.

author: BBC News (World)
message: Unconfirmed reports suggest over 80 people were killed during the U.S. raid in Caracas, including Venezuelan security officers and Cuban military advisors.

author: Edward Helmore (The Guardian)
message: Maduro is reportedly being flown to New York City to face a 2020 narco-terrorism indictment. This is the first time the US has captured a sitting head of state since Noriega.

author: Fox News Politics
message: Secretary of War Pete Hegseth: 'This is America First; this is peace through strength.' Hegseth confirms Maduro is currently aboard the USS Iwo Jima.

author: AFP News Agency
message: PHOTO: President Trump shares image of a blindfolded, handcuffed Nicolas Maduro in a gray sweatsuit aboard a U.S. Navy vessel.

author: Pam Bondi (Attorney General)
message: The Department of Justice has unsealed a new indictment against Maduro and Flores for cocaine importation and possession of destructive devices. They will face the full wrath of American justice.

author: Al Jazeera English
message: China and Russia condemn the U.S. military action in Venezuela, calling it a 'flagrant violation' of international law and Venezuelan sovereignty.

author: The Wall Street Journal
message: Trump signals U.S. oil companies will be sent to Venezuela to 'rebuild and manage' the nation's nationalized oil industry following Maduro's removal.

author: CNBC Breaking
message: Oil markets react sharply to Venezuela news. WTI crude fluctuates as traders weigh the potential for U.S. control over Venezuelan reserves.

author: NBC News
message: Protests erupt outside the White House and the UN Plaza in San Francisco against the U.S. bombing of Caracas and the seizure of Maduro.

author: El Nacional (Venezuela)
message: Tensions high in Caracas as supporters of the PSUV gather to protest the 'abduction' of Maduro. Security forces' loyalty remains divided.

author: CBS News
message: Law enforcement sources say Maduro's plane has landed at Stewart Air National Guard Base in New York. He is being moved to Manhattan via helicopter.

author: ABC News
message: Crowds gather outside the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn as an armored convoy arrives carrying the deposed Venezuelan leader.

author: Washington Post
message: Legal experts question the 'self-defense' justification for the raid, noting no prior armed attack by Venezuela occurred before the U.S. strikes.

author: Christian Amanpour (CNN)
message: The capture of Maduro is a massive blow to Russian influence in the Western Hemisphere. Putin's most prominent Latin American ally is now in a New York jail cell.

author: The Hill
message: Democrats in Congress split: many who previously called for Maduro's ouster now criticize Trump's 'unauthorized' use of military force.

author: Miami Herald
message: Celebrations in Doral, Florida. The Venezuelan diaspora reacts with joy to the news of Maduro's capture after years of exile.

author: VICE News
message: Inside 'Operation Absolute Resolve': Sources say the mission was months in the making, involving detailed rehearsals of the breach at Fort Tiuna.

author: The Guardian
message: Indictment alleges Maduro and the 'Cartel of the Suns' ran a corrupt patronage system that flooded the US with thousands of tons of cocaine.

author: Politico
message: Speaker Mike Johnson briefs House on Venezuela; says no plans for long-term U.S. troop deployment, but 'operational control' is the goal for now.

author: Telemundo News
message: Cilia Flores, Maduro's wife, also faces life in prison. Allegations include accepting bribes to facilitate drug meetings in 2007.

author: Bloomberg Politics
message: US Ambassador Mike Waltz tells UN Security Council the raid was a 'surgical law enforcement operation' against fugitives of justice.

author: Sky News Breaking
message: UN Secretary-General expresses 'grave concern' over the escalation in Venezuela and the status of international law following the U.S. intervention.

author: CBC News
message: Timeline of escalation: U.S. pressure had been building since September 2025 with strikes on suspected narco-boats in the Caribbean.

author: Le Monde in English
message: European leaders remain cautious. France and Germany call for a return to democratic order but stop short of endorsing the military capture.

author: The Independent
message: Trump administration officials say Delcy Rodriguez is the 'interim' contact point in Caracas, despite her earlier denunciations of the U.S.

author: NPR Politics
message: The 'Noriega Precedent': How the U.S. is using the 1989 Panama invasion as a legal blueprint for the prosecution of Nicolas Maduro.

author: MSNBC
message: New DOJ indictment does not refer to 'Cartel of the Suns' as an organized group, but as a 'corrupt patronage system' within the Venezuelan state.

author: USA Today
message: Federal marshals increase security at the Southern District of New York (SDNY) ahead of Maduro's expected arraignment.

author: The Daily Beast
message: Sources: Maduro's son, Nicolasito, remains at large. U.S. bounty on top Venezuelan officials remains active.

author: Daily Mail Online
message: Inside the cell: Maduro reported to be held in high-security wing of MDC Brooklyn, the same facility that held Ghislaine Maxwell and Sam Bankman-Fried.

author: Vox News
message: Explained: Why the U.S. claims Maduro's 2024 election win was fraudulent, providing the political cover for 'Absolute Resolve.'

author: HuffPost
message: Human rights groups warn of a power vacuum in Venezuela as U.S. forces maintain a 'security perimeter' around key oil infrastructure.

author: New York Post
message: MADURO IN MANHATTAN: The dictator arrives at court. Heavy police presence blocks off Worth Street for the high-profile prisoner transfer.

author: CNN World
message: Maduro appears in court wearing blue jail scrubs. He reportedly told the judge: 'I am a prisoner of war... I am a decent man.'

author: BBC Breaking
message: Nicol√°s Maduro pleads NOT GUILTY to all charges, including narco-terrorism and cocaine importation, in a Manhattan federal court.

author: The Guardian World
message: Lawyers for Cilia Flores say she sustained 'broken ribs' during the U.S. military extraction and requires urgent medical attention.

author: Reuters Legal
message: Judge Alvin Hellerstein orders Maduro to be held without bail. Next hearing set for March 17, 2026.

author: TIME
message: The end of the Bolivarian Revolution? With Maduro in a U.S. prison, Venezuela faces its most uncertain chapter since the rise of Hugo Chavez.

author: Atlantic Council
message: Analysis: The capture of Maduro marks a radical shift in U.S. foreign policy toward 'direct kinetic enforcement' of domestic indictments abroad.

author: Newsweek
message: Polls show 62% of Americans support the capture of Maduro, but 55% are concerned about a potential long-term military entanglement in Venezuela.

author: Financial Times
message: Trump tells reporters on Air Force One: 'We're going to make Venezuela great again. Their oil will pay for the rebuilding.'

author: AP News
message: As of Jan 6, 2026, Maduro remains in U.S. custody. The world watches Caracas to see if the military will hold or if the government will collapse entirely.
